section.title: Microstructure
section.para: The &oof2; µ is the digitized representation of a physical microstructure and is the primary object upon which &oof2; operates. The µ is a container for &skels; and &meshes;. The Microstructure Page in the main &oof2; window has two main purposes: it creates and manages µ objects, and it creates and manages pixel groups.

The anatomy of the Microstructure Page is shown in . The Microstructure Page per se starts below the Navigation Bar. At the top is the Microstructure Chooser, which selects the µ on which most of the other components of the page operate. Below that are buttons for manipulating µs; and two panes, the Info Pane and the Pixel Group Pane.

section.title: Microstructure Page Buttons
section.para:
The buttons all correspond in a straightforward fashion to items in the menu, and the details are provided there. The first row of buttons is used to create a new µ.
Use the New... button to create a completely new µ without any associated &images; ().
Use the New from Image button to create a µ from an ℑ that's already loaded in another µ ().
Use the New from Image File button to load a new ℑ and create a µ from it ().
Use the New from Orientation Map button to load a new Orientation Map and create a µ from it ().
After using any of these buttons, the Microstructure chooser at the top of the page will automatically switch to the new µ.

Most of the New… buttons bring up a dialog box in which the name and size of the µ can be set. If any of these parameters is set to automatic, a suitable default value will be used. The manual pages for the menu commands explain what automatic means in each context. In the &oof2; GUI, an input field will display <automatic> in italics when its value is automatic. See for the details.

The second row of buttons manipulate the µ that's selected in the Microstructure chooser.
Rename
Rename the current µ ().
Copy
Make a duplicate of the current µ (). The copy will include copies of all the &images; and pixel groups in the original, but not the orientation maps, &skels;, or &meshes;.
Delete
Delete the current µ, as well as all of its &skels; and &meshes; ().
Save
Save the current µ in a file (). The only difference between the Save... button and the File/Save/Microstructure command in the menubar is that the Save... button saves the µ named in the Microstructure Chooser, whereas the menubar command asks for a µ in a dialog box.

section.title: The Info Pane
section.para: The Info Pane on the left lists the sizes of the currently selected µ, as well as the names of any &images; and orientation maps it contains.

section.title: The Pixel Group Pane
section.para: The Pixel Group Pane creates and manipulates pixel groups. Using pixel groups is in principle optional in &oof2;, but they provide a convenient way of storing and operating on sets of pixels. The buttons on the left side and right sides of the pane correspond to items in the menu. The center of the pane is a list of all of the pixel groups defined in the current µ.

The seven buttons to the left of the central list operate on the pixel groups themselves: creating a new group, automatically

putting all pixels into groups, renaming or copying an existing group, deleting a group, deleting all groups, or setting a group's meshable flag. All except for New, Auto, and Delete All operate on the pixel group that's currently selected in the list.

The four buttons to the right of the central list operate on the contents of the currently selected group. Add button adds the currently selected pixels to the currently selected group. The Remove button removes the currently selected pixels from the group, and the Clear button empties the group entirely. The Info button prints information about the group in the Message window.
